protocol_name: Isolation of cyanophages by plaque assays
protocol_name_html: Isolation of cyanophages by plaque assays
description:
More than 40 years ago, Safferman and Morris (1963) used the plaque assay method to isolate the first cyanophage that infects a freshwater filamentous cyanobacterium, Plectonema boryanum. Since then, this approach has been used successfully to detect and isolate a number of different phages infecting marine Synechoccocus and Prochlorococcus (e.g., Suttle and Chan 1993; Waterbury and Valois 1993; Wilson et al. 1993; Sullivan et al. 2003).

The advantages of this method are that results are easily interpreted as plaques formed on pigmented lawns can be easily identified. Since a plaque is the result of a single infection event, the virus can be easily purified and cloned. The first part of the procedures described as follows: (1) preparation of base plates and (2) preparation of top agar/agarose are applicable also for bacteriophage plaque assays.

groups.group_name: Suttle Laboratory of Marine Molecular Microbiology and Virology

collections.protocol_name: Isolation and life cycle characterization of lytic viruses infecting heterotrophic bacteria and cyanobacteria
collections.protocol_name_html: Isolation and life cycle characterization of lytic viruses infecting heterotrophic bacteria and cyanobacteria

authors: Mathias Middelboe, Amy M. Chan, and Sif K. Bertelsen
guidelines:
For example, purified agar or agarose (1% w/v) is added to your media of choice and autoclaved. This will provide a support base for the top agar/agarose overlay as well as nutrients for the host cells. For best results, use plates within 1 week of pouring.

Tip: plates can be fast-tracked: dry plates at 37°C; leave lids slightly ajar; monitor closely to prevent over drying.

Considerations: Depending on the composition of the media used, the addition of solidification agents (in particular the combination of high salinity seawater-based media and common agar such as Bacto Agar) can often result in the formation of precipitates when autoclaved together. These flocks can sometimes interfere with interpretation of the plaque assay. Moreover, impurities in common agar can negatively affect the growth of the host cells. Here are some suggestions on how to reduce the formation of these precipitates. Some testing may be required to determine the best combination to use for your particular situation.

a. Do not use common agar; rule of thumbthe whiter the agar, the cleaner it is.
b. Use commercially available purified agar or agarose; or clean common agar using a washing procedure such as the one outlined in Waterbury and Willey (1989).
c. Reduce the salinity of seawater media with purified water; e.g., to 20-25 psu.
d. Add purified agar or agarose to autoclaved media aseptically and then melt the agar/agarose in the microwave (bring to a short boil 2-3 times to completely dissolve the agar/agarose).
e. For cells that will grow in artificial media, prepare media and gelling agent at 2x concentration and autoclave separately. When cooled to ca. 60°C, gently mix the gelling agent into the media and dispense immediately.
f. In the case of artificial media, add agar/agarose to filter-sterilized media and melt the gelling agent in the microwave

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 2 of Isolation of cyanophages by plaque assays
source_data.protocol_name: Isolation of cyanophages by plaque assays
source_data.protocol_name_html: Isolation of cyanophages by plaque assays
source_data.annotation: Prepare 100 mL portions of 0.4 to 0.5% (w/v) of purified agar, agarose or low-melting point (LMP) agarose (i.e., Invitrogen #15517-022) in your media of choice. Although LMP agarose can be quite expensive, it is recommended for temperature sensitive samples and cells, since it solidifies at ca. 25°C. Purified agars, as well as low-melting point agars and agaroses are available for a range of lower temperatures (consult the following websites for more details: www.sigmaaldrich.com and www.invitrogen.com)
source_data.thread_text: Prepare 100 mL portions of 0.4 to 0.5% (w/v) of purified agar, agarose or low-melting point (LMP) agarose (i.e., Invitrogen #15517-022) in your media of choice. Although LMP agarose can be quite expensive, it is recommended for temperature sensitive samples and cells, since it solidifies at ca. 25°C. Purified agars, as well as low-melting point agars and agaroses are available for a range of lower temperatures (consult the following websites for more details: www.sigmaaldrich.com and www.invitrogen.com)

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 5 of Top agarose
source_data.annotation: For best results (smooth lump-free top agar), use freshly prepared top agar/agarose since repeated re-melting of solidified agar/agarose can give inferior results.

components.data: Prepare target indicator cells.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Prepare target indicator cells.
For use in "Isolation of cyanophages by plaque assays"
source_data.authors: Mathias Middelboe, Amy M. Chan, and Sif K. Bertelsen

components.data: Grow the cyanobacteria in liquid media, harvest in exponential growth and adjust cell density to about 10<sup>7</sup> to 10<sup>8</sup> cells/mL.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Grow the cyanobacteria in liquid media, harvest in exponential growth and adjust cell density to about 10<sup>7</sup> to 10<sup>8</sup> cells/mL.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 1 of Preparing target indicator cells
source_data.annotation: If necessary, cells can be concentrated by gentle centrifugation and resuspended in media. Preliminary testing may be required to determine the best cell density to use for your particular host organism. The objective is to start with a lawn of cells that will have the capacity for additional growth during the length of the assay. Depending on the growth rate of the target cells, one can expect plaques to appear on the lawn as early as 3 to 4 d to weeks after infection. The initial lawn of cells will be very faint in color. However, the lawn will develop into an evenly distributed dense layer of cells within 7 to 10 d. If the lawn is too thin, plaques will go undetected. If the lawn is too thick, the cells could run out of nutrients prematurely which may result in poorly developed plaques.
source_data.thread_text: If necessary, cells can be concentrated by gentle centrifugation and resuspended in media. Preliminary testing may be required to determine the best cell density to use for your particular host organism. The objective is to start with a lawn of cells that will have the capacity for additional growth during the length of the assay. Depending on the growth rate of the target cells, one can expect plaques to appear on the lawn as early as 3 to 4 d to weeks after infection. The initial lawn of cells will be very faint in color. However, the lawn will develop into an evenly distributed dense layer of cells within 7 to 10 d. If the lawn is too thin, plaques will go undetected. If the lawn is too thick, the cells could run out of nutrients prematurely which may result in poorly developed plaques.
source_data.body: If necessary, cells can be concentrated by gentle centrifugation and resuspended in media. Preliminary testing may be required to determine the best cell density to use for your particular host organism. The objective is to start with a lawn of cells that will have the capacity for additional growth during the length of the assay. Depending on the growth rate of the target cells, one can expect plaques to appear on the lawn as early as 3 to 4 d to weeks after infection. The initial lawn of cells will be very faint in color. However, the lawn will develop into an evenly distributed dense layer of cells within 7 to 10 d. If the lawn is too thin, plaques will go undetected. If the lawn is too thick, the cells could run out of nutrients prematurely which may result in poorly developed plaques.

source_data.protocol_name: Isolation of cyanophages by plaque assays
source_data.protocol_name_html: Isolation of cyanophages by plaque assays
source_data.annotation: If high titers are expected, serial dilutions of the sample may need to be performed.
source_data.thread_text: If high titers are expected, serial dilutions of the sample may need to be performed.
source_data.body: If high titers are expected, serial dilutions of the sample may need to be performed.

components.data: Adsorb 50 to 100 µL sample (as is, and 10-fold serial dilutions, up to ca. 3 levels) to 0.5 mL target cells under the usual culturing conditions (e.g., for Synechococcus sp. strain DC2, constant 5–25 µmol quanta m–2s–1, at 25°C), agitate occasionally to encourage adsorption of phage to host.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Adsorb 50 to 100 µL sample (as is, and 10-fold serial dilutions, up to ca. 3 levels) to 0.5 mL target cells under the usual culturing conditions (e.g., for Synechococcus sp. strain DC2, constant 5–25 µmol quanta m–2s–1, at 25°C), agitate occasionally to encourage adsorption of phage to host.

components.name: Section

components.data: After 1 h, transfer virus: host mixture to 2.5 mL soft agar.
components.name: Description

components.data: Assay
components.name: Section

components.data: Quickly and gently vortex the mixture and pour the entire tube contents onto the surface of the agar plate.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Quickly and gently vortex the mixture and pour the entire tube contents onto the surface of the agar plate.

components.data: Assay
components.name: Section

components.data: Working rapidly, gently rock and swirl the plate to spread the mixture evenly onto the plate surface before the agar starts to gel.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Working rapidly, gently rock and swirl the plate to spread the mixture evenly onto the plate surface before the agar starts to gel.

components.data: Assay
components.name: Section

components.data: Set aside on a flat surface to harden (about 1 h).

source_data.description: Set aside on a flat surface to harden (about 1 h).

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 9 of Isolation of cyanophages by plaque assays
source_data.protocol_name: Isolation of cyanophages by plaque assays
source_data.protocol_name_html: Isolation of cyanophages by plaque assays
source_data.annotation: For best results, the total volume of cells + virus + soft agar is between 3 to 4 mL. Larger volumes would make it easier to pour, but is not recommended as the top layer would be too thick, and plaques could form on top of one another.
source_data.thread_text: For best results, the total volume of cells + virus + soft agar is between 3 to 4 mL. Larger volumes would make it easier to pour, but is not recommended as the top layer would be too thick, and plaques could form on top of one another.
source_data.body: For best results, the total volume of cells + virus + soft agar is between 3 to 4 mL. Larger volumes would make it easier to pour, but is not recommended as the top layer would be too thick, and plaques could form on top of one another.

components.data: Assay
components.name: Section

components.data: Seal plate with parafilm, flip plates upside down.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Seal plate with parafilm, flip plates upside down.

components.data: Assay
components.name: Section

components.data: Incubation of plates under constant low light conditions (5 to 25 µmol quanta m<sup>–2</sup>s<sup>–1</sup>) will produce darker lawns thus allowing for easier detection of plaques.
components.name: Description

source_data.protocol_name: Isolation of cyanophages by plaque assays
source_data.protocol_name_html: Isolation of cyanophages by plaque assays
source_data.annotation: Plaques will appear within 1 to 2 weeks, depending on the growth rate of the host cells.

components.data: Note the number of plaque forming units (PFUs), plaque size, and morphology.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Note the number of plaque forming units (PFUs), plaque size, and morphology.

components.data: Assay
components.name: Section

components.data: Choose a well-isolated plaque on a plate that contains less than 100 PFUs.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Choose a well-isolated plaque on a plate that contains less than 100 PFUs.

components.data: Assay
components.name: Section

components.data: Harvest the plaque using a Pasteur pipette: gently press the tip of the pipette into the plaque to the bottom agar; using gentle suction, remove the plug.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Harvest the plaque using a Pasteur pipette: gently press the tip of the pipette into the plaque to the bottom agar; using gentle suction, remove the plug.

components.data: Assay
components.name: Section

components.data: Transfer the plug to 1 mL media and vortex briefly to break it up.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer the plug to 1 mL media and vortex briefly to break it up.

components.data: Assay
components.name: Section

components.data: Place the tube at 4°C and allow the phages particle to elute from the plug overnight to form a plaque lysate.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Place the tube at 4°C and allow the phages particle to elute from the plug overnight to form a plaque lysate.

components.data: Assay
components.name: Section

components.data: Vortex and centrifuge the sample (ca. 12,000g for 10 min) to pellet cyanobacteria and agar.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Vortex and centrifuge the sample (ca. 12,000g for 10 min) to pellet cyanobacteria and agar.

components.data: Assay
components.name: Section

components.data: Transfer the supernatant to a new tube; typical titer of the plaque lysate can be 10<sup>4</sup> to 10<sup>5</sup> PFU mL<sup>–1</sup>.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Transfer the supernatant to a new tube; typical titer of the plaque lysate can be 10<sup>4</sup> to 10<sup>5</sup> PFU mL<sup>–1</sup>.

components.data: Assay
components.name: Section

components.data: Repeat steps 14 to 19 for a minimum of 3 plaques. Choosing plaques with different morphologies may result in the isolation of different phages.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Repeat steps 14 to 19 for a minimum of 3 plaques. Choosing plaques with different morphologies may result in the isolation of different phages.
